title: Docker Build Fails Step 3/11 : COPY
body:
#### System information
```
docker version
Client: Docker Engine - Community
 Version:           19.03.12
 API version:       1.40
 Go version:        go1.13.10
 Git commit:        48a66213fe
 Built:             Mon Jun 22 15:43:18 2020
 OS/Arch:           windows/amd64
 Experimental:      false

Server: Docker Engine - Community
 Engine:
  Version:          19.03.12
  API version:      1.40 (minimum version 1.12)
  Go version:       go1.13.10
  Git commit:       48a66213fe
  Built:            Mon Jun 22 15:49:27 2020
  OS/Arch:          linux/amd64
  Experimental:     false
 containerd:
  Version:          v1.2.13
  GitCommit:        7ad184331fa3e55e52b890ea95e65ba581ae3429
 runc:
  Version:          1.0.0-rc10
  GitCommit:        dc9208a3303feef5b3839f4323d9beb36df0a9dd
 docker-init:
  Version:          0.18.0
  GitCommit:        fec3683
```

#### Expected behaviour
Docker build should work.

#### Actual behaviour

```
PS > Get-Content .\Dockerfile | docker build -
Sending build context to Docker daemon   2.56kB
Step 1/11 : FROM golang:1.14-alpine as builder
1.14-alpine: Pulling from library/golang
df20fa9351a1: Already exists
ed8968b2872e: Pull complete
a92cc7c5fd73: Pull complete
00abe362642d: Pull complete
e0491c15e88f: Pull complete
Digest: sha256:d6deb50437547fd7226890aa19b075fbf7f5063e3c0d7a2eaf7fb41d11069013
Status: Downloaded newer image for golang:1.14-alpine
 ---> 30df784d6206
Step 2/11 : RUN apk add --no-cache make gcc musl-dev linux-headers git
 ---> Running in 4fe8cd3f23d2
fetch http://dl-cdn.alpinelinux.org/alpine/v3.12/main/x86_64/APKINDEX.tar.gz
fetch http://dl-cdn.alpinelinux.org/alpine/v3.12/community/x86_64/APKINDEX.tar.gz
(1/19) Installing libgcc (9.3.0-r2)
(2/19) Installing libstdc++ (9.3.0-r2)
(3/19) Installing binutils (2.34-r1)
(4/19) Installing gmp (6.2.0-r0)
(5/19) Installing isl (0.18-r0)
(6/19) Installing libgomp (9.3.0-r2)
(7/19) Installing libatomic (9.3.0-r2)
(8/19) Installing libgphobos (9.3.0-r2)
(9/19) Installing mpfr4 (4.0.2-r4)
(10/19) Installing mpc1 (1.1.0-r1)
(11/19) Installing gcc (9.3.0-r2)
(12/19) Installing nghttp2-libs (1.41.0-r0)
(13/19) Installing libcurl (7.69.1-r0)
(14/19) Installing expat (2.2.9-r1)
(15/19) Installing pcre2 (10.35-r0)
(16/19) Installing git (2.26.2-r0)
(17/19) Installing linux-headers (5.4.5-r1)
(18/19) Installing make (4.3-r0)
(19/19) Installing musl-dev (1.1.24-r9)
Executing busybox-1.31.1-r16.trigger
OK: 163 MiB in 34 packages
Removing intermediate container 4fe8cd3f23d2
 ---> b4bb5a6aa06f
Step 3/11 : COPY go.mod go.sum /app/
COPY failed: stat /var/lib/docker/tmp/docker-builder822170195/go.mod: no such file or directory
```

#### Steps to reproduce the behaviour
From PowerShell:
```
git clone https://github.com/ledgerwatch/turbo-geth.git
cd turbo-geth
Get-Content .\Dockerfile | docker build -
```

Looks like docker doesn’t understand which folder need to build. Try “docker build . -“ or “docker build - .”
Or without Get-Content, I usually do: “docker build -t turbo-geth .”

Ok, I did `docker build -t turbo-geth .` and it got a lot further but it still failed...

```
<truncated>
...
Done building.
Run "./build/bin/tg" to launch turbo-geth.
Removing intermediate container 04c84072700f
 ---> 8c3409f700a0
Step 7/11 : FROM alpine:latest
latest: Pulling from library/alpine
df20fa9351a1: Already exists
Digest: sha256:185518070891758909c9f839cf4ca393ee977ac378609f700f60a771a2dfe321
Status: Downloaded newer image for alpine:latest
 ---> a24bb4013296
Step 8/11 : RUN apk add --no-cache ca-certificates
 ---> Running in 0c02231b0f0b
fetch http://dl-cdn.alpinelinux.org/alpine/v3.12/main/x86_64/APKINDEX.tar.gz
fetch http://dl-cdn.alpinelinux.org/alpine/v3.12/community/x86_64/APKINDEX.tar.gz
(1/1) Installing ca-certificates (20191127-r4)
Executing busybox-1.31.1-r16.trigger
Executing ca-certificates-20191127-r4.trigger
OK: 6 MiB in 15 packages
Removing intermediate container 0c02231b0f0b
 ---> 98aa9e2854e7
Step 9/11 : COPY --from=builder /app/build/bin/geth /usr/local/bin/
COPY failed: stat /var/lib/docker/overlay2/c8a7da7a4e1818e4a44c1ce6649a7fc2572fb866b42b2c258f0f56b2aa90a381/merged/app/build/bin/geth: no such file or directory
```

It is a wrong executable name in the docker file.

In these lines:

```
COPY --from=builder /app/build/bin/geth /usr/local/bin/

EXPOSE 8545 8546 8547 30303 30303/udp
ENTRYPOINT ["geth"]
```

try to replace it with 

```
COPY --from=builder /app/build/bin/tg /usr/local/bin/

EXPOSE 8545 8546 8547 30303 30303/udp
ENTRYPOINT ["tg"]
```
It completed after making the above changes. I'll play with it now 😄
Somewhat related question: This is only building `tg` and not any of the RPC stuff, right? E.G. `rpcdaemon`?
There is file: Dockerfile.alltools
@MysticRyuujin if I can ask you to try building Docker in this branch and check if your Docker issue is fixed there: https://github.com/ledgerwatch/turbo-geth/pull/834

I haven't done an extensive tests or anything but the following worked:

```
git clone -b 832-dockerfile-fixup --single-branch https://github.com/ledgerwatch/turbo-geth.git
cd turbo-geth
docker build -t turbo-geth .
```

I've temporarily given up going the Docker route since it's not all that clear to me how to run the individual pieces together, so I just spun up a Linux VM instead.
@MysticRyuujin - what is 1-st thing you will try to test after build done? If I know your use-case, then maybe I can create for it  docker-compose.yaml

So right now I'm just trying to get a feel for how to run the services, how long it'll take to sync, disk requirements, etc. and then additionally I just want to "poke it"

What I have setup, which to me seems like a common use case, is

1. Three `supervisor` services (could also be systemd, or 3 individual dockers).
  a. `/opt/turbo-geth/build/bin/tg --datadir=/data/tg --identity MysticRyuujin-TurboGeth --port 30304 --private.api.addr=localhost:9090`
  b. `/opt/turbo-geth/build/bin/rpcdaemon --chaindata /data/tg/tg/chaindata --http.addr="0.0.0.0" --http.vhosts="*" --http.corsdomain="*" --http.api="eth,debug"`
  c. `/opt/turbo-geth/build/bin/restapi --private.api.addr=localhost:9090 --http.addr="0.0.0.0:8080"`

I'm aware that with `b` I could go with the remote API here, instead of `chaindata`, probably best for the docker setup...

If that was dockerized, I could see that being a common setup/scenario for a lot of people.

Thanks for extended answer. 
FYI: “make run-web-ui” starts page which using restapi, there is no useful features, but can see how much space takes every bucket in DB.
What exactly does "run-web-ui" do? I run headless, does it generate a new binary that hosts a webpage or is this suppose to be ran on a non-headless machine and it just brings up a browser window?
Yes, it opens browser. But it can be run on another machine and ui will have button to set address:port of restapi.
It appears that requires dependencies that are not listed (yarn?)

yes, it's javascript package manager (probably will also require `node`). 
deps are listed in: https://github.com/ledgerwatch/turbo-geth/tree/master/debug-web-ui#prerequisites

I will add this dependencies to docker-compose and other docs.

@MysticRyuujin done with docker-compose:
docs: https://github.com/ledgerwatch/turbo-geth/pull/841/files#diff-04c6e90faac2675aa89e2176d2eec7d8R138
docker-compose.yml: https://github.com/ledgerwatch/turbo-geth/pull/841/files#diff-4e5e90c6228fd48698d074241c2ba760R1

FYI: i removed ENTRYPOINT from Dockerfile to improve go build caching. So, Dockerfile and Dockerfile.alltools now are same :-)  

Anything else you need?

This is awesome. I'll play with it but you can consider this closed. For my own education though it would appear that I need to follow the instructions 1-4 prior to running step 5 in order to build/run the docker, is that correct?

I only ask because that's difficult to do on Windows, it's not a problem for me but others might find it helpful for there to be a hub.docker.com to pull from 😉

I don't know if it's possible...but...in order to run this docker on a windows host I think you need to include `--ipcdisable` I've never gotten Geth to run hosted on Windows without that command.

Not sure the best way to handle that though...as I'm sure it's useful for other people.

So, because I'm running Turbo-Geth on another machine right now, I wanted to just build the debugui to check it out.

So I cloned/pulled the latest master and I did:
```
cd turbo-geth\debug-web-ui
docker build -t debugui .
```

I got this warning (not sure if it means anything):
```
[3/4] Linking dependencies...
warning " > bootstrap@4.5.0" has unmet peer dependency "jquery@1.9.1 - 3".
warning " > bootstrap@4.5.0" has unmet peer dependency "popper.js@^1.16.0".
warning "react-scripts > @typescript-eslint/eslint-plugin > tsutils@3.17.1" has unmet peer dependency "typescript@>=2.8.0 || >= 3.2.0-dev || >= 3.3.0-dev || >= 3.4.0-dev || >= 3.5.0-dev || >= 3.6.0-dev || >= 3.6.0-beta || >= 3.7.0-dev || >= 3.7.0-beta".
```

Then I tried to launch it:
```
docker run --name debugui -p 3000:3000 --network my-bridge debugui
yarn run v1.22.4
$ react-scripts start
ℹ ｢wds｣: Project is running at http://172.18.0.7/
ℹ ｢wds｣: webpack output is served from
ℹ ｢wds｣: Content not from webpack is served from /app/public
ℹ ｢wds｣: 404s will fallback to /
Starting the development server...

Done in 1.18s.
```

"instructions 1-4 prior to running step 5" - oh, actually digits in Readme are independent, probably need to mention it somehow (or just convert digits to list).

"there to be a hub.docker.com to pull from" - we will add a bit later

"--ipcdisable" - right, I will add now

"warnings from debug UI" - it's ok, it's warnings from some dependency lib. Can disable them on current package manager: https://github.com/yarnpkg/yarn/issues/6672

"Done in 1.18s." - I just released docker-compose.yml file, you can see example of run parameters there. That frontend server requires `stdin_open: true` to show logs and don't stop. I also added section to Readme about docker-compose. Maybe some day we will embed UI files into restapi binary.
Hmmm, was looking for the docker run equivalent to stdin_open: true but maybe I didn't look hard enough, I'll try again tomorrow
Not 100% sure, but I think it's `-it`
Just that server inside UI docker is interactive - it may ask you some questions depends on it's mood
